review_blob: Pours orange, with a small short lasting white head. Smell is of is of tropical fruits with some citric notes. The taste is also driven by hops, albeit suprisingly toned down from what I expected from the smell. Some grain and caramelly tones in the background. The issue for my part with this beer is that it lacks carbonation, as well as the punch that will lift this from being a average pale ale to something great. I would love to try this with more carbonation and some dryhopping.

Pours almost pitch black, with a one finger tan head. Smell is of some charred wood and alder wood smoke. Texture is oily, and the carbonation is low, but it suits the smoke driven flavours. I also detect leather, chocolate and bitter coffe. I would love to try this with some game meat, as the peated flavours from the local Stjrdalsmalt would go very well dark meat.

Another great brew from 7 Fjell. Pours a clear copper colour. Nice one finger head. Smells of pines, resing and grapefruit. Taste is likewise dominated by pine, resin and grapefruit with some carameltones in the background. Dry and nice mouthfeel, and it manages not to become as cloying sweet as ambers often tend to do. Great beer that I could easily drink a sixer of with some propper BBQ.

Pours pitch black with a big frothy head that laces well. Smell is dominated by hops that smells like cat piss and sweat. The first taste that hits the mouth is the hops, but they soon turn into liqurice and charcoal and burnt malt. Dry finish. Solid beer, but I would like to see a more complex hop profile.

Another beer from Austmann with fruit pureee in it, this time around apricot. The smell is of wheat, sligth yeast, apricot and american hops. Taste wise it is pretty much the same, but the hops play a more dominant role than the apricots, which are a bit hard to detect. The beer does however taste very refreshing, and the apricot seems to bind the flavours well together. I think this will be a great summer beer.

Pours a murky orange-straw colour, good frothy white head. Smells of ripe bananas, white bread, belgo yest with some brett lurking in the background. Taste is much the same, with focus on the bananas and brett. Nice bretty aftertaste. This beer went perfectly with mussels.
beer_name: Lervig Art Collection Funky Moi Rye Saison

review_blob: Pours a murky straw colour, good head that stick nicely to the glass. Smell is dominated by sweet belgian yeast notes, some wheat and ripe apples. Taste is driven by the wheat accompanied by the ripe sweet apples. Slight tartness in the after taste, however fairly short lived. It does lack some of the peppery saison flavour in my oppinion. Easy drinking beer, but it was a bit dissapointing, I had expected more from this beer.

This ranks as one of the worst micro brewed beers I have ever tasted. It looks like a wheat ale, but the smell is dominated by popcorn and butter. The same goes for the taste, butter and sour wheat all the way. I am glad I only bought a sampler of this. It makes me wonder though, do they even taste their own beer before they start selling it?

Bottle at home, nr0862 Pours pitch black with a dense tanned head. Aroma of figs, prunes, some oak, rounded burnt notes and some alcohol. Tastes of dried dark fruits, massive taste of sweet dark malts, some oak. Medium bitterness and a silky smooth aftertaste of dried fruits and oak. Only thing holding this beer back from max score is that I would have liked to see a bit more body and a little less carbonation. A recomended brew if you can get hold of it.

Black with absolutly no light shining through, small head with large boubles. Smells of pine, some fruit and a little burnt note. The taste is hop driven with lots of pince, hop cones and resin, but it is surprisingly easy drinking with a moderate bitterness. Mouthfeel is oily, yet at the same time drying out your mouth. Very easy drinking beer, only letdown is the relatively low carbonation. I hope this will become one of their regular beers as it is one of the best ones that has come out of this brewery.

Bottle @Diskoteket, Trondheim. Dark copper colour withouth any head or carbonation. Smells of horsblanket, hay and layers upon layers of funk. The palate serve the same funkyness alongside a nice lemony tartness. Mild accidic aftertaste. Great beer that I was very pleased to find at my local bar.

Hazy copper colour with a medium white head. Smells of biscuits, some caramell, sweet fruits and some minty tones. Taste has the same busicut taste that I got on the nose alongside sweet fruits. Hard bitterness that turns into a minty afterstate along with malty tones. Medium carbonation, which fits the beer nicely. A good beer from Austmann, but it does not rock my world.

Bottle at home. Pours a yellow hazy colour, with a medium white head that laces well. Smells of hop cones, resin, sweet fruits, some caramell and light malts. The tate has a nice malty caramell tone accompanied with a hard taste of resin, pine, sweet tropical fruits. Harch bitterness that dries out the mouth. Long hop driven aftertaste. Nice beer that is true to the style of west coast IPAs.

Cloudy orange colour with a nice dense head that laces well. Smells of spicy belgian yeast, apricots and pomegranades . The taste is much the same, but with a more rounded sweet taste of canalope melons as well as the apricot. Medium bitterness that leads on to a great taste of grapefruit and light malts. All in all a very solid beer that has some interesting elements to it.

Colour is golden hay. Smells of citric fruits and some cereals and grains. Taste is similiar, however here the malts are dominant over the hops. Lots of grains and cereals in the taste. There is nothing wrong with the beer, although there are not much going on flavour vice either.

A bland ghost of what this beer used to be a couple of years ago. Something must surely have gone wrong in the brewing process. The beer is dark reddish and does not have any smell besides pale malts, and the taste is of bland tones of pale malts with some wage notes of burnt malt. Not a beer I would recomend.

A smoky version of their regular stout. Pitch black with a forthy tan head that laces well. Smells of burnt wood, some peat, and dark malts. Taste is quite dry with a distinct peated cahracter that follows the taste all the way. Medium long aftertaste. A great session beer that is intresting enough to be drunk by the numbers.

By far the best beer Ive had from this place in ages. The collour is hazy golden copper with a nice white head. Smells of pine and citric fruits. Taste is sweet caramell, grapefruit and pine. A bit cloying, but noting that lets down the beer much. All in all, a great DIPA that I will by again.

2012 vintage. Pours pitch black with a frothy mocca coloured head that laces beautifully. Smells of honny, fresh pine and spruce as well as a rounded smell of burnt malts. Taste is much the same as the smell, in adition a slight taste of port and slight oxidation becomes present in the aftertaste. Such a pleasent surprise, great craftsmanship.

Pours a dark brown almost black colour. Smells of campfire and acidic green aples. Taste is shortlived smoke, before a sharp acidic apple viegar taste masks all other flavours. This bottle surely has to be off, I had to empty the entire bottle in the sink.

Pours a deep ruby red with a short lived pink head. Smells of ripe morellos, slight tartness, hints of oak and some artificial cherry candy smell. The taste is also dominated by morellos, cherry stones, some malt, light tartness with traces of oak in the aftertaste. A really nice easy drinking Kriek, great to find this in Norwegian grocary stores.

Dark brown colour with a medium beige head. Smells of banana esters, cinamon, some chocolate and a tad bit of cloves. Taste is much the same, with a heavy focus on the esters. Rich cramy mouthfeel, and a long lasting aftertaste. Does not however compete with some of the quads in this league.

Slow gusher. Clear honey orange in the glass with a frothy white head. Smell is of funky barnyard, sea bucktorn and wheat. The taste has a rich brett taste that both has barnyard and horseblanket as well as some apricot and other sweet fruit flavours. The sea bucktorn is not to dominating, but contributes to the general tartness and complexity of this beer. Surprisingly mild acidity and tartness in this beer, just pure brett domination all the way. I had this beer on several occasions when it was first released, both draft and bottle, and I have to say that it has developed rather nicely. Great stuff!

Nice nutty brown colour with a dense off white head that lasts forever. Smells of grain, burnt toast, buscuits, some toffe and caramell. The taste is dominated by burnt toast, mild chocolate, biscuits and some dusty cellar. Soft carbonation that fits the beer nicely, medium to full mouth feel. I have now tried this from both bottle and draft, both have been equally nice. Solid beer.

Vicously black with a quick failing mocca coloured head. Nose is mostly hops, dark berries, soy and leather. The tase is down the same line, sweet but not overtly cloying. Soy, leather, dark berries and some hops. Very nice and rich mouthfeel. This is for sure the best beer Ive had from Sierra Nevada!

A really disapointing beer from Trollbryggeriet. The looks of the beer is very nice, hazy honny color with a dense white head. The smell is of cerial mix, some slight smoke and dusty belgian yeast notes. However, the flavour is dominated by a sweetness from the malt that masks moss of the other flavours. Short lived aftertaset. In total, this beer comes of as a unbalanced brew with too much sweetness.

Pours a beautifull dark ruby red with a short lived pinkish head that leaves no lacing. Smells really nice of balsamico, funky barnyard tones and blueberries. However, the flavour is a letdown. The tartness on the nose is almost nonexictent in the flavour, the dominating flavour is blueberries. In the aftertaste a taste of wheat shines through. The best of the berry collection Ive tasted this far. I would have liked to see a barrel aged version of this.

Dark and rich in liquirice flavour on the nose and the palate. Layers upon layers of liquirice, espresso, and chocolate. Nice to have such a rich imperial stout that is not as sweet as they often are. Another great beer from Amager!

Bottle at home. Pours almost black with a ruby shine. Nose is dominated by hops, spruce, resin and some citric fruits. Medium to hard bitterness followed by a bit harsh taste of burnt sugar. Aftertaste is dominated by this burnt sugar, some roast and citric notes. Overall a nice beer, but I was a bit let down by the harsh burnt flavor.

Maybe one of the worst beers Ive had years. Smelled like a really bad homebrew with some christmas spices alongside some serious funk. 
Taste had most of the flavors from the nose, but was dominated by funky notes of bad homebrew and slight infection. So far I have not tasted anything impressing from this brewery.

The smell is dominated by burnt wood and dark chocolate notes. Tastes of chocolate, some breadiness and mild tones of dark berries. Some slight funk y dry yeast notes in the aftertaste along with a dry chocolate/cocoa taste. I would have expected the cherries to be more prominent, but it was a very drinkable beer nonetheless.
beer_name: Lindheim / Lost Abbey Vince of Change

review_blob: A really solid beer from Lindheim. Nice hazy straw-colored beer with a huge fluffy white foam. The dominating smell is of ripe mangos and funky barnyard notes.The flavors follows the same scheme as the smell, with a nice dry finish. A very sessionable beer that would go well with light summer dishes.

2012 vintage, bottle. Pours pitch black, oily, small mocha head that disappears quickly. Smells of bourbon, some oak and very round tones of burnt malt. Phenomenal taste that really lives up to the hype. Lots of dark fruits, bourbon, vanilla, oak and layers upon layers of burnt tones. A must-try beer.

Hazy straw colored beer with a two finger high white head. Smells of mild Belgian yeast notes, some hay, slight bobble gum, and a distinct metallic smell. The taste is of sweet apricots, hay, pale malts and some slight earthy yeast notes. Fruity aftertaste of apricots. An ok beer.

Sampled at Trondheim Bryggerifestival. Great to find a barrel aged beer from a local brewery. Full flavored beer that still is a bit to young, but it has a lot of potential nonetheless. Lots of bourbon and sticky caramel notes, full bodied with a long-lasting aftertaste.

A straight west coast IPA. Resin and pine on the nose, the same goes for the flavor. The flavor is a bit of a letdown compared to the nose, but the all the classic IPA flavors are there. Nice dryness to the aftertaste, but it does not stand out among all the other competitors in this genre.

Clear straw colored with a huge fluffy white head. Strong smell of barnyard flavors, hay and green grapes. The flavor is dominated by peppery and yeasty saison notes accompanied by a very neat hop profile from the Nelson hops. Nice slightly tart finish dominated by grapes and hay. This is one of the best Saisons Ive ever had.

A very subtle rendering of the Belgian Double style. Dark cola color with a dense white head. Smells of chocolate, dark malts and some burnt caramel. Tastes of much the same as the nose, but it has a surprisingly sour finish. The sourness and the slightly watery mouthfeel makes this beer fail as a Belgian Double, still drinkable though.

Very nice interpretation of the traditional Strdalsl. The most stunning smoked flavor I have ever tasted in a beer, it feels like drinking a freshly cut alder wood forrest. Seasonal beer for fall/winter, the brewer actually makes his own malt in a traditional sinnhus (smoking lodge), kudos!

Pours pitch black and oily with a small mocha colored head. Smells of molasses and booze, with a backdrop of smoke and burnt wood. Taste is one the sweet end of the imp.stout scale, rich and sweet, heavy bitterness, followed by a very complex aftertaste of smoke, licorice, soya and burnt wood. Good now, but probably much better in a couple of years.
beer_name: Ngne  / Mikkeller / Brewdog Horizon Tokyo Black
